page.title: 01FARMING in BLINDCRAKE
page.content: There are 12 farms in this area ranging in size from 30 to 600 acres. All are family farms run by fathers and sons with 6 or so employees and some seasonal casual labour. The land is not suitable for arable farming,any cereals grown being used on the farm. Grass is used for pasture or conserved as hay or silage. Farming is mainly mixed with dairy, suckler beef and sheep. There are 6 dairy herds of mainly Freisans, aver- age 60 head, housed in cubicle sheds and traditional byres. The milk is made into cheese at Aspatria. Sheep flocks range from 50 to 800 head of mainly Swaledale ewes crossed with Suffolk or Blue Leicester. Fat lambs are sold in the local markets of Cockermouth, Wigton, Penrith and Carlisle. (See{"FARM LIFE in BLINDCRAKE")
